awd_abstract_narration:
Molecular Dynamics of Centrosome-Nuclear Interactions

Intellectual Merit
Centrosomes and nuclei are the two most fundamental organelles in eukaryotic cells, as they provide for the basic properties of life: motility and inheritance. Centrosomes organize the microtubule cytoskeleton that is required for cell structure and organelle movement. Nuclei maintain the genetic material that provides instruction for nearly every cell action. Interactions between these organelles play important roles in cell polarity, motility, development, and division. While genetic and molecular analyses reveal a complex framework of proteins that interconnect these two organelles, how these interactions are established and maintained remains poorly understood. Moreover, virtually nothing is known about how these physical interactions influence the replicative cycles of centrosomes and nuclei. The long-term goal of this project is to understand the mechanisms that coordinate centrosomal and nuclear cycles. Through the deletion of a kinesin molecular motor, previous work has developed a novel means to uncouple these two organelles and yet maintain cell viability. This deletion leads to supernumerary centrosome accumulation and to errors in cell division that ultimately impact cell growth. The project will utilize combinations of light and electron microscopy, and laser ablation of cell organelles to determine how centrosome replication is governed by nuclear attachment. Efforts will establish whether multiple attachment mechanisms are at play and distinguish between their functional roles, address nuclear vs. cytoplasmic requirements for spindle assembly in a closed mitotic system, and determine how the kinesin motor participates in the attachment process. Overall the objectives will lead to an understanding of the mechanisms by which centrosomes engage nuclei and how these two organelles coordinate their functions to maintain cell viability and genomic stability.

Broader Impact 
The research projects capitalize on state of the art live cell microscopy, coupled with analyses by electron microscopy. Undergraduate students from two local top-notch teaching colleges (Siena and Russell-Sage) will be exposed to this technology, in a laboratory environment that significantly extends their coursework. Students will be taught to assemble molecular constructs with various fluorescent tags and how to image these molecules inside live cells. The methods will constitute a fundamental set of skills for many different cell biology applications and are designed to stimulate continued interest in biology as a long-term career. Students will be supervised but also responsible for all aspects of data collection and analysis, with the driving goal of producing publication quality results. Students will be provided with opportunities to present their results at local and national meetings. The PI will also continue an active role in community service to lecture at local colleges, primary and secondary education institutions.

por.por_cntn:
Interactions between nuclei and centrosomes play important roles in eukaryotic cell polarity, motility, development, and division. Although the complex interplay of centrosomes and nuclear components during cell division has received significant attention, associations between these organelles during interphase are poorly understood. Our preliminary data identified a mechanism to uncouple centrosome-nuclear interaction, enabling us to ask novel questions about centrosome replication and coordination between interphase and mitotic cycles. Through gene disruption, we identified a novel activity for a kinesin motor protein (Kif9), enabling centrosomes to separate from nuclei and move independently in the cytosol. Through combinations of live cell imaging, molecular genetic manipulations, biochemistry, and electron microscopy, we demonstrated the following key results.

Our work developed a mechanism whereby Kif9 is restricted to the nuclear envelope, the motor binds cytoplasmic microtubules and effects a minus end directed depolymerization that draws the centrosome up to the nuclear periphery. In this way, there is a constant reinforcement of centrosome/nuclear interactions that determine their position in a cell.

This interaction is fundamental for it enables the centrosome to remain adjacent to the nucleus for proper integration of one and only one centrosome into the nuclear envelope during cell division. Centrosomes that fail to integrate into nuclei during division undergo normal duplication and separation processes, but are unable to form mitotic spindles in the cytosol. This result indicates that spindle assembly requires nuclear docking and some type of nuclear organization for cell division.

The Kif9 deletion also resulted in cells with multiple centrosomes, and resulting microtubule arrays in a common cytoplasm. In contrast to vertebrate tissue culture cells, and reflecting what is commonly seen in many protists, multiple microtubule arrays maintained exclusive territories in a common cytosol. We further identified a novel activity from a microtubule-associated protein (Ase1) that maintains this spatial organization of the microtubule arrays.

The results outlined above are reflected in three primary publications from this project, two collaborative papers, and one review book chapter. We trained four undergraduates in modern cell biology methods; three of these students (1M, 2F, 1URM) have gone on to graduate level biosciences programs. This project has further contributed to the research infrastructure at our home institution by maintaining state of the art equipment and expertise. The project has also advanced the cell biology field by demonstrating novel motor protein activities, fundamental organelle dynamics, as well as resolved a long-term question in our model system as to the nature of nuclei and centrosome interactions.
